conclusion: Determine the dynamic friction coefficient between the ground and the logs.
Three logs A, B, and C are stacked, forming an isosceles triangle with a top angle of 120°.
Log A is in equilibrium, so the forces acting on it must balance.
The weight of log A is mg, acting downward.
Normal forces from logs B and C, N1 and N2, act at an angle due to the 120° angle between them.
Resolve normal forces N1 and N2 into horizontal and vertical components.
Each normal force makes an angle of 60° with the vertical.
Vertical equilibrium for log A: N1 cos(60°) + N2 cos(60°) = mg.
N1 + N2 = 2mg.
Horizontal equilibrium for log A: N1 sin(60°) = N2 sin(60°).
N1 = N2 = mg.
Each log (B and C) has its weight mg and the normal force from log A (mg) acting on it.
The total downward force on each log is 2mg.
The logs B and C are on the verge of sliding, so the frictional force equals the maximum static friction.
The normal force on each log from the ground is 2mg.
The frictional force f is given by f = μ (2mg).
The horizontal component of the normal force from log A must be balanced by friction.
The horizontal component of the normal force from log A on log B or C is mg sin(60°).
mg sin(60°) = μ (2mg).
